Hint 3 (Stronger Hint): The study of how choices are made given that decision makers face constraints.
Wants and needs of decision makers are greater than the limited resources available.
What is given up when a choice is made.
Studies how specific individuals and firms interact and make decisions.
Examines the economy as a whole.
A statement about how things objectively are.
A statement about how we think things should be.
Comparing the marginal benefit and marginal cost of a decision.
Individuals who use all available information to achieve their goals.
A direct monetary payment associated with a choice.
A non-monetary cost of a decision, often the value of the next best option forgone.
Change in the Y-variable divided by the change in the X-variable on a graph.
The value of the Y-variable when the X-variable is zero.
The amount of a good or service that consumers purchase at a particular price.
The amount of a good that a firm is willing and able to produce at a given price.
The point where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied.
Price and quantity demanded of a good or service move in the opposite direction.
When the price of a good increases, the quantity supplied increases.
When the price of one good decreases, it causes an increase in demand for another.
When the price of one good decreases, the demand for the other good also decreases.
A market with many buyers and sellers, identical products, and easy entry/exit.
A table showing the quantity demanded of a good at various prices.
A table showing the quantity supplied of a good at various prices.
A good for which demand increases as consumer income rises.
A good for which demand decreases as consumer income rises.
Occurs where the supply and demand curves intersect.
Occurs when the quantity demanded exceeds the quantity supplied at the current price. (Also Excess Demand)
Occurs when the quantity supplied exceeds the quantity demanded at the current price. (Also Excess Supply)
Latin phrase meaning "all other things held constant."
The amount of a good or service that consumers purchase at a particular price.
The amount of a good that a firm is willing and able to produce at a given price.
A government-imposed maximum price that can be charged for a good or service.
A government-imposed minimum price that can be charged for a good or service.
A situation where the market on its own fails to allocate resources efficiently.
A cost or benefit caused by a producer that is not financially incurred or received by that producer.
Gross Domestic Product; The total value of all final goods and services produced within a country's borders.
The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising.
The state of being without a paid job but available to work and actively seeking.
Consumer Price Index; the average price of all goods and services that a household consumes.
(Nominal GDP / Real GDP) x 100.
GDP holding prices fixed at the prices in the base year.
Market value of goods and services produced, calculated using current year prices.
Unemployment caused by the time-lag involved in workers moving from one job to another.
Occurs when there is a mismatch between worker skills and employer needs.
Occurs when individuals lose their job because of changes in production (business cycles).
The number of employed plus the number of unemployed individuals.
Goods produced and then used in the production of another good.
Goods and services purchased by the actual user of the product.
Method of calculating GDP by summing spending by households, firms, government, and foreigners.
Goods that last a long time (longer than 3 years) and are bought infrequently.
Goods that do not have a long useful life and are purchased frequently.
The market value a firm adds to a product.
The degree of wealth and material comfort available to a person or community.
An economic state where all available labor resources are being used efficiently.
The sum of frictional and structural unemployment.
(Labor Force / Civilian Population) x 100.
Individuals who want a job but have stopped looking because they believe no jobs are available.
Total spending in the economy (C + I^P + G + NX).
Shows the relationship between disposable income (Y−T) and consumption (C).
Level of consumption that does not depend on disposable income. (AC)
Marginal Propensity to Consume: The fraction of an additional dollar of disposable income that is spent on consumption.
Spending by firms on new capital and new homes, excluding inventory changes. (IP)
1/(1−MPC); shows how an initial change in spending leads to a larger change in Y.
−MPC/(1−MPC); shows how a change in taxes affects equilibrium output.
Income remaining after deduction of taxes (Y-T).
The total value of assets minus the total value of liabilities.
The natural tendency of the economy to move towards and away from full-employment output.
A significant decline in economic activity spread across the economy, lasting months.
The lowest point of economic activity in a business cycle before recovery begins.
A period when the economy moves from a trough to a peak.
The highest point of economic activity in a business cycle before a recession.
A sustained, long-term downturn in economic activity.
MPS: The fraction of an additional dollar of disposable income that is saved. (1-MPC)
The line on the Aggregate Expenditure model where Y = AE.
Goods that have been produced but not yet sold.
Changes in government spending (G) or taxation (T) to influence the economy.
Government actions to move the economy closer to full-employment output.
Occurs when government spending (G) is greater than tax revenue (T).
The total amount of money that the government owes to lenders.
Fiscal policies that automatically enact in response to changes in production level.
Spending by the government on goods and services, like defense and infrastructure. (G)
The value of a country's total exports minus its total imports. (NX)
Changes in government spending or taxation decided upon by the government annually.
The total amount that the US Government owes to private lenders.
A measure comparing a country's total debt to its total economic output.
American Reinvestment and Recovery Act (Stimulus Package) aimed to speed recovery from the Great Recession.
Occurs when tax revenue (T) is greater than government spending (G).
Payments made by the government to individuals for which no good or service is received in return (e.g., welfare).
Actions by the central bank involving altering the money supply to change interest rates.
The Fed; the central bank of the United States responsible for monetary policy.
The buying and selling of Treasury bonds by the Fed to alter the money supply.
The interest rate that banks charge one another for short-term (overnight) loans.
Required Reserve Ratio: The fraction of deposits that banks are required to keep on reserve.
An economy involving trading goods and services directly for other goods and services.
A function of money; accepted by sellers for goods and services.
A function of money; used as a way to measure the value of goods and services.
A function of money; its value does not deteriorate quickly.
Money that has no intrinsic value other than being a means of exchange.
Goods that have intrinsic value but can also serve as money (e.g., gold).
The ability for money to be used as a form of payment quickly.
A promise to pay back a specified amount of money at a future date, often with interest.
The relationship between the amount of M1 money demanded and the interest rate.
The total amount of M1 money in circulation, controlled by the Federal Reserve.
The monetary gain from purchasing a bond (Value of Bond - Price of Bond).
Federal Open Market Committee; the Fed body that determines monetary policy.
When many depositors withdraw their funds from a bank simultaneously due to fears of insolvency.
Unconventional monetary policy where a central bank purchases assets to inject liquidity.
AD Curve: Curve showing equilibrium level of spending at every price level.
AS Curve: Curve showing the amount firms are willing to produce at various price levels.
A period of stagnant economic growth accompanied by high inflation.
Anything that changes the Aggregate Expenditure curve other than price.
An event that suddenly changes the price of a commodity or service, affecting AS.
Policy response to a negative supply shock that saves jobs at the cost of higher prices.
Policy response to a negative supply shock that keeps prices stable at the expense of jobs.
On AD: Changes in this affect autonomous consumption and planned investment, shifting AD.
On AD: Changes in G or T directly influence the AE curve and thus shift the AD curve.
On AD: Changes in the money supply by the Fed alter interest rates and shift the AD curve.
AS Shifter: Changes in costs of labor or capital shift the AS curve.
AS Shifter: Improvements in technology increase the AS curve.
Full-Employment Output: The level of output when all resources are utilized efficiently.
Components of aggregate expenditure that do not depend on the level of national income.
A change in the price level affecting purchasing power and thus consumption.
A change in the domestic price level affecting net exports.
As an AS Shifter: Can reduce the stock of capital and shift the Aggregate Supply curve left.
In AD-AS Model: At a given price level, the aggregate quantity demanded exceeds aggregate quantity supplied.
In AD-AS Model: At a given price level, the aggregate quantity supplied exceeds aggregate quantity demanded.
